awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Fundamental Electronic Device Performance and Reliability Investigation on Chalcogenide- and Oxide-based N- and P-type Materials for Large Area/Flexible Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
Large area/flexible electronics presents new opportunities for applications benefiting society, such as low- cost, flexible and self-powered sensors, wearable, and even biocompatible electronics. These systems may include "smart" medical bandages that monitor the healing of wounds and medical triage patches that monitor vital signs. Also, light-weight and rugged flexible decals are a potential application for inventory tracking, pollution monitoring, structural reliability of buildings/bridges in urban areas, etc. Currently, a typical fabrication approach to enable circuitry for these applications will use organic materials in a complex integration scheme with inorganic materials "hybrid approach"  that will be more costly compared to the proposed work. In addition, a serious limitation of the hybrid approach is device and circuit performance limitations due to exposure of organics to the ambient. To enable high performance systems applications for large area electronics such as "smart" bio monitoring patches, flexible sensors, RFIDs, and microcontrollers, the incorporation of low cost, non-silicon thin-film transistor materials compatible with mechanically flexible properties is essential. Moreover, the flexible application requires substrates processed at relatively low temperatures (< 180°C) compared to conventional silicon-based chip manufacturing. To address this performance gap at low cost, this research proposes exploring an entirely inorganic, non-hybrid semiconductor technology using chalcogenides (sulfur- and tellurium-based materials) and oxides (zinc oxide-based, nickel oxide and tin oxide materials). Using these semiconducting materials will result in a revolution of large-area/flexible electronics by enabling straightforward integration of multiple components (i.e., energy storage/harvesting, displays, and sensors) on a single substrate. Furthermore, they will have a resounding impact on the Internet of Things, medical, defense, and sensors by enabling technologies where it may not be practical and cost effective for silicon. Finally, the education/outreach objectives include engaging with middle school STEM educators for on-campus research in the PI"s lab and incorporating the experience into innovative curriculum plans to take back to their students. In addition, there will be implementation of "units of learning" that incorporate large-area/flex technology into advanced-level courses while also providing undergraduate research opportunities.


The objective of this proposal is to fundamentally explore the use of inorganic, low temperature (< 180ºC) chalcogenide- and oxide-based n-type and p-type thin-film semiconductors for low-cost, large-area/flex- compatible devices and circuits. The research plan consists of four (4) phases: (I) materials evaluation; (II) device fabrication; (III) device characterization; and (IV) device simulation/modeling. Using physical and electrical characterization along with modeling/simulation, a comprehensive investigation will provide fundamental device performance and reliability understanding. This work will provide the opportunity to have Cd- and Pb-free materials for p- and n-type semiconductors with high carrier mobility and electrical stability for implantable or wearable electronics. Furthermore, the demonstration of large-area/flex- compatible p/n junctions, junction field effect transistors, and thin-film transistors will truly take large- area/flex processing to new heights and permit complementary circuit capabilities, such as thin film amplifiers and logic circuitry, that have not been demonstrated using appropriate processing conditions (i.e., low temp) for integration into sensors, smart bandages, detectors, RFIDs, etc. This work addresses current challenges in large-area/flex-compatible circuitry where all-inorganic, n- and p-type semiconductor devices, and circuits are vital because an organic-only or a partially organic hybrid approach has more pronounced long-term degradation of organic-based devices. Therefore, inorganic materials and devices are preferred in order to create the needed circuitry. Using these semiconducting materials will result in a revolution of large-area and flexible electronics by enabling straightforward integration of multiple components such as energy storage/harvesting, displays, and sensors on a single substrate. Furthermore, they will have a resounding impact on the Internet of Things, medical, defense, and sensors by enabling technologies where it may not be practical and cost effective for silicon.

por.por_cntn:
With bipartisan passage of the CHIPS and Science Act, the overall goal is to bring back and reinvigorate advanced semiconductor manufacturing here in the United States to ensure a globally competitive advantage and further enhance national security. In addition, continued innovation is expected to make this a reality. Future semiconductor integrated circuit technologies (ICTs) in the areas of biomedical, wearable/flexible electronics, sensors, energy, defense, and the "Internet of Things (IoT)" will have increased levels of functionality, resulting in increased performance in computing, detecting, and sensing. Furthermore, these future ICT needs may not be solved by the most used semiconductor in computer chips today - silicon, or other typical materials. Thus, new innovations in semiconductor manufacturing will require new materials to enable the needed ICT functionality, such as large-area and flexible electronics in addition to the current push for monolithic 3D integration. This will require that these materials be implemented using temperatures as low as 100oC up to 450oC, which are significantly lower than typical temperatures used in integrated circuit manufacturing.

 

Therefore, this project was conceived and executed to fundamentally explore the performance and reliability of non-silicon, inorganic semiconductor materials incorporated into electron devices such as diodes, capacitors, junction field effect transistors (JFETs), thin-film transistors (TFTs), and metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs). In addition, a byproduct of the CHIPs Act is the substantial need that will exist for preparing an educated workforce with the appropriate training needed to fill the advanced manufacturing roles that are required. Thus, course development and outreach activities were developed and implemented to encourage pursuit of a career in semiconductor technology and/or consider obtaining a graduate degree in STEM.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Several non-silicon, inorganic semiconductors that can be implemented in this temperature range were investigated using materials characterization and analysis followed by the fabrication of the devices mentioned above using as close to industrial manufacturing processes as possible to mimic real-world ICT fabrication techniques. The semiconductors investigated were: cadmium telluride (CdTe), cadmium sulfide (CdS), zinc-based oxide semiconductors (e.g., ZnO and IGZO), molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), and an organic-inorganic hybrid halide perovskite (e.g., MAPbI3). After device fabrication, electrical characterization and degradation testing coupled with analysis was executed to determine the performance and reliability of the electron devices. As part of electrical/reliability testing, the influence of the device fabrication was also evaluated. To achieve robust understanding, the various materials and electrical characterization involved corroboration with theoretical modeling and simulation. In turn, a feedback loop was created that improved both characterization and modeling/simulation to achieve reproducible electron devices. From here, reliability testing was explored to ascertain how electrically active defects would degrade devices over time to assess their lifetime of operation. The reliability investigation was able to determine similar and different degradation mechanisms when comparing to conventional, mainstream transistors used in integrated circuits today. Furthermore, electrical testing innovations occurred which improved the ability to evaluate perovskites materials used in photodetecting applications. This CAREER Award, in part, supported 5 PhD students that graduated, and the intellectual merit generated 22 peer-reviewed products.

 

Broader Impacts:

A research methods course was established for freshmen and sophomores in the Undergraduate Success Scholars Program (a first-generation retention program) to expose them to what research entails. Overtime this class continuously increased in enrollment to "max out" the last few offerings. The course included topics for potential undergraduate researchers, such as: fundamentals of research, design of experiments overview, publishing, graduate school preparation, applying to graduate school, and aspects of academic careers (i.e., exposure to proposal writing, teaching, and service).

 

Starting in the spring of 2022, the PI's planned advanced elective lab course was implemented. This lab course covered experiments related to diodes and metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs) to provide experiential learning for students and expose students to customary advanced electrical characterization techniques used in industry to explore MOSFET performance and reliability.

 

In addition, a pilot Research Experience for Teachers (RET) took place for one week. Ten local middle, ninth, and tenth grade public and independent school district career and technical education teachers participated. Throughout the week, cutting edge researchers and graduate students shared their knowledge and best practices in their classrooms and labs to further develop and/or enhance the teachers' classroom curriculum. Additionally, the teachers learned more about the semiconductor workforce needs in our region, and how they can cultivate an interest in pursuing those career pathways to their students.
